data.title: Black screen macOS 3.0
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 current master
macOS 
MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015)
2,7 GHz Intel Core i5
8 GB 1867 MHz DDR3
Intel Iris Graphics 6100 1536 MB
Xcode compiled

**Issue description:**
when I start godot I get a black screen. I need to resize the window before I can see the ui.
in addition to that the performance is really bad at the moment. zooming in 3d view but also things like opening the node section.
there is also randomly an issue which pops up, tells me godot is not working anymore but godot still works.

**Steps to reproduce:**
compiling on Xcode. starting the binary. with the current master: de0045cf1b0a5e20fbf74da192039d344ee8d0c7

**Link to demonstration video:**
https://youtu.be/-8JEwtKx9so

data.title: implemented scrolling factor for precision trackpads
data.body:
for now its only used in platform: osx and windows
support for almost all ui elements
This solves basically the same issue than #7559 and fixes #492 and #3913 
the difference is, that it sends a new property (factor) with each mouse button event. this factor is 1 by default and any action taken with the scroll even will be multiplied with the factor.
With the macOS trackpads I now can sent hundreds of scroll events and the scrolling is smooth.
#7559 solves the issue of fast scrolling by waiting for enough events that a total scroll offset of one is reached and than sends the event. which is less impact for the rest of the code but it makes the scrolling less smooth.

https://youtu.be/HPSmZnp9gCs

data.title: Web builds: Zip automatically; Fix on Windows; Parallel wasm/asm.js builds
data.body:
This goes with my previous commits 335fdea581f677fea55d20f0e23b4c7d7c75664b and 6e2bf31e5a8f3dbe18e31b1aff9c26ee184ad8c8.
This commit in particular fixes WebAssembly builds on Windows.

These changes modify the build process for `platform=javascript` so that no manual zipping is necessary, the output is a `godot.opt(.debug)(.webassembly).zip` file that must only be renamed to either `javascript_release.zip` or `javascript_debug.zip`.

Also correctly sets the unique suffix for WebAssembly build files, so it's possible to switch between building asm.js and WebAssembly without completely rebuilding every time.

Also fix building WebAssembly and asm.js on Windows
Actually building and running 3.0 web builds is not yet working though, see #7689

data.title: Better handling of joypad device IDs.
data.body:
Now `InputDefault` is responsible for giving out joypad device IDs to the platform, instead of each platform handling this itself.
This makes it possible for c++ modules to add their own "custom" gamepad devices without the risk of messing up events in case the user also has regular gamepads attached (using the OS code).
For now, it's implemented for the main desktop platforms.
Possible targets for future work: android, uwp, javascript

data.title: Last line missing in the editor to edit a uniform mat4
data.body:
Godot 2.1.2.stable.official (from Steam) on windows

The menu to edit a "uniform mat4" in the editor is missing the 4th line.
`uniform mat4 MM;`
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13542748/23179846/9fa41a92-f86f-11e6-87e4-2982d12fec7b.png)

And the name of my variable is "MM" not "Mm" as displayed in the editor.
And in the editor, the letter that describe the 4th column is "o" but in the shader language it's "w".

data.title: Add more options to Node.duplicate()
data.body:
to decide whether signals, groups and/or scripts should be set in the copied nodes or not; it's default value makes the method include everything, as usual.

For 2.1 I added a `flags` parameter to keep compatibility. But for _master_ I've taken the opportunity to convert the existing `use_instancing` parameter to a flag (`DUPLICATE_USE_INSTANCING`) which will make more expresive the scripts using it. Probably also a bit more cluttered so maybe the prefix should be changed to `DUP_`-.

(This is the version for _master_ of #7855.)

Motivation: my use case is to copy a hierarchy of nodes in a behaviorless fashion because I just want a visual copy of the original node so I can apply certain effects on it. With these flags I can control what kind of duplicate I want.

Furthermore, it avoids some error prints (which lag the game) about signals with targets outside the subtree being copied.

I believe more people will find this useful.

data.title: Add flags parameter to Node.duplicate()
data.body:
to decide whether signals, groups and/or scripts should be set in the copied nodes or not; it's default value makes the method work as usual, that is, including everything. So **non-breaking change.**

(This is the version for _2.1_ of #7856.)

Motivation: my use case is to copy a hierarchy of nodes in a behaviorless fashion because I just want a visual copy of the original node so I can apply certain effects on it. With these flags I can control what kind of duplicate I want.

Furthermore, it avoids some error prints (which lag the game) about signals with targets outside the subtree being copied.

I believe more people will find this useful.

data.title: Replace misuse of list iteration
data.body: :hand:

data.title: Security of the new Multiplayer API
data.body:
I've been playing around with the new Multiplayer API and I noticed there is a huge security/logic issue.

Each node can be in either Master or Slave mode.
If the node is set to **slave** it will **accept RPC** from other nodes.
The problem is that there is **no way of knowing which peer called** that remote procedure.

I think there are two ways to deal with this problem:

1. Let the user handle it in his own networking function
   @reduz suggested adding something like `SceneTree::get_rpc_id()` to get the called ID.
   This will require the user to check that value in every RPC and it's state outisde RPCs
   might become confusing

2. Have the user specify which network peer actually owns a node. The idea is: 
   - Add new functions `set_owner_network_id(id)` and `get_owner_network_id()` to configure which client ID
     is allowed to call RPC on that node.
   - The engine will discard received RPC automaticaly if the caller ID is different from the one configured locally to own that node.
     - Optionally, as suggested by @reduz could report a `client_misbehave` signal
     - Optionally, expose client kicking to GDScript (supported by ENet, both nicely and forcefully). Probably dedicated feature/PR.
   - Additionally I think we could get rid of the `master`/`slave` GDScript keyword and just keep `remote` and `sync`.
   - Nodes should inherit owner like the current master/slave mode (which could be removed).
   - `is_network_master` will then bascially be a check if the remote owner ID is the same as the current network ID.
   - The node is owned by the local peer unless specified otherwise.
     - Optionally we could automatically intherit `1` (ID of the server) if no override is set and the SceneTree network peer is a client peer.
       (bascially, clients will be "slave of the server" unless otherwise specified).

Option 1 is fastest and easier to implement, but I feel like it's a bit hacky. An will require more effort from users.

Option 2 is a bit more complex and will require more work on the engine. But I feel the structure would be more robust and save a lot of time to game developers.


**Link to minimal example project:**

I've setup a small repo with a simple client/server architecture using the Multiplayer API.
I plan to setup a small test set to check for regressions / behavior complaince in the future: inheritance, cheating attempt, correct delivery client<->server, and client<->client (will still go through the server, but not call on it).
You can [check it out here](https://github.com/Faless/gd-multiplayer-test).
For now only the impersonation test is shown.

data.title: Cache DynamicFont resource for Android (2.1)
data.body:
Tested with 16.5MB otf font file
* NotoSansCJKkr-Medium.otf - https://www.google.com/get/noto/#sans-kore )

Measure time between changing scenes has Label with DynamicFont

First & Third scene
![screenshot from 2017-02-20 22-33-59](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8281454/23127342/0bbba7fc-f7be-11e6-9edb-bd4729e8ff15.png)
Second scene
![screenshot from 2017-02-20 22-39-28](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8281454/23127348/0efa92d4-f7be-11e6-855a-d58b84a0ab85.png)



test result with 2.1.2 official templates

Device  | first scene | second scene | third scene
--------|---------|--------|-------
PC-Linux|32ms     |11ms    |9ms
Nexus 6p |101,621ms|54,098ms|92,951ms
iPhone 4s | 451ms | 212ms | 183ms

test result with caching font (based on 2.1.2) ~~ON at Project Settings > Locale~~

Device  | first scene | second scene | third scene
--------|--------|--------|------
PC-Linux|103ms   |49ms    |46ms
Nexus 6p |258ms |53ms    |52ms
iPhone 4s | 498ms|170ms|145ms

Fix #7428

I will make for another PR for master after this accepted.
Because, I can't test on Android device with current master branch.

update : add iPhone 4s test result

edit : test result changed after changing a way to cache

data.title: Get rid of some compilation warnings.
data.body:
These appear by default on Mageia Linux v6. Not all compilation warnings
were fixed but it's a start.

data.title: Interpolated particles
data.body:
I found out that when a `Particles` node has an `amount` higher than FPS while moving (here set at 100 with a lifetime of 0.5), the result is not exactly as expected:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/23109463/d1ef5d92-f719-11e6-8c3d-2e1ee659733c.png)
As you can see, it emits "packets" of particles, instead of emitting through a continuous line, and will always be bound to that no matter how much is the `amount`.

The reason why is that the current Particles system emits particles only once per frame, and all at the same location, instead of compensating for the time spent between frames.

Would it be possible to have it interpolate particles emitted between frames?

data.title: Windows: Close audiodriver sooner on exit
data.body:
In #7839 I see the same error that was fixed in #7833 occuring on the
Windows platform. This moves the audio driver closing to the same place
in OS_Windows::finalize() as it is in OS_X11::finalize()

This fixes #7839

**Operative system:**

**Godot version:**
Godot 3.0 (5e3fc7d)

**Issue description:**
Opening Godot, it shows the project manager, but opening a project it shows a black screen.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Build the lastest Godot commit on macOS, create a new project and open it.

data.title: Feature request: NodeRef (node reference)
data.body: From times to times I crash a whole scene while moving (reparenting) a node, and it takes a lot of time to fix (and test) things if you have many scripts. While NodePath's make things cleanear, they won't keep track of the node if you reparent it. So, that's my suggestion: adding a NodeRef property type so one can easily reference another node in its code.

data.title: A way to browse loaded resources from zip/pck files
data.body:
When loading a resource pack, the only way to know the contents is to append a (known) file with the data. 
Even if the resources are accesible from `res://`, these are not visible by Directory or any other way.

What I ask for is a tool/class that can browse current and loaded resources like working with a real, unique filesystem, it could be really useful to manage DLC, level packs, packed mods and things like that.

data.title: Merge meshes
data.body:
Merging meshes into one is very useful for performance because draw calls get batched, especially for static objects, or even procedurally generated ones.

I don't think that such a thing exists in the API yet (correct me if I'm wrong). It can probably be done by actually getting all vertices per surface from a Mesh and joining them together, but this is extremely slow to do in GDScript, and requires custom code in C++.

In Unity, the Mesh class has a `CombineMesh` method with some options like how submeshes (surfaces) are treated, or if transforms have to be applied etc: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Mesh.CombineMeshes.html

Asked on QA: https://godotengine.org/qa/12531/merge-meshes

data.title: camera parameter of VisibilityNotifier3D enter_camera and exit_camera signal is boolean not Object
data.body:

README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha

data.title: Fixed Line2D editor doesn't respond to input
data.body:
The Line2D editor was unresponsive, it needed to override the correct input function (which was renamed).
I also had to move a misplaced return statement which prevented point addition.
